title: New Sorcery keystone idea: Supernova
body:
Intended users: Champions that mix spell weaving and diving such as Diana, Akali, and Elise.

Effect: After landing a spell on an enemy champion, charge up with arcane energy and gain a supernova stack. Landing multiple spells gains additional stacks (max 4). 3 seconds after landing the first spell, release a burst of arcane energy from your champion (think a radius (the size of randuins omen) that deals 15-80 (based on level) (+15% AP) (+25% bonus ad) adaptive damage **per stack**.

 Cooldown something like 35-10 based on level.

Thoughts?

replies.body: I dunno much about the numbers, but that sounds like a really cool idea. Gives assassins more to choose from other than Electrocute.

yeah, dark harvest is a gimmick and predator is just a stupid jungle free gank.

This idea sounds actually good
Actually, OP's suggestion is basically the same as Electrocute. What would make it different enough to justify its existence?

How is it the same as Ele, lol?

It doesn't require three attacks/abilities, just one.
Its damage scales with your capability to hit abilities, up to four.
It's AoE. It isn't guaranteed hit and can be avoided.

DH and Ele is acording to you also the same I suppose since it's single-target burst.

Superficial differences which don't really matter in practice.

It doesn't require three attacks... but you will deal 3 attacks when you dive in and all-in an opponent anyway.
It scales with how many abilities you hit... but the damage per stack will be much lower (or it would be OP), so the fully stacked damage will be similar to other Keystones. Maybe a tad higher to compensate for the lack or reliability, but not much.
It's not guaranteed hit... but it's pretty much fool-proof anyway. The size of Randuin, around an Akali or Diana diving in your team? You won't avoid it.

Which leaves... it's AoE. Yeah, that's kinda a noticeable difference, if you can hit 4 or 5 enemies, that's a lot more damage than Electrocute, but damage on the frontline will probably not really matter in the end. It's a bit light, as the only point to justify its existence. (Also, Electrocute is technically AoE, but the radius is really tiny, so I won't nitpick about that.)

DH and Electrocute, on the other hand, have a **very** meaningful difference: one is strong in early game, the other is a late-game scaling choice. There are clear situations where you want one over the other. Can you give me a similar clear situation where sometimes Electrocute is the right choice, and sometimes it's Supernova?

- If you know you want loaded damage aginst key target, Ele, If you'll roam bot a lot and want to spread your damage to both targets, Nova
- If you want more flexibility being sure you can shut down the target with extra damage even when you already used combo, sacrificing the measure of the damage
- When you want to just zone off enemy, yet again, sacirifcing damage
etc.

As If other keystones had much more diversity than this, lol. Aery is extra damage on first spellcasts just like Comet, except Comet is chosen when you poke with any CC, Aery is chosen when you don't or when you have enchant.

When choosing between Aftershock, Guardian and Grasp, you either dive with CC, are Support or are Bruiser, even less decision-making and these keystones are vastly different.

When choosing between Press the Attack and Elec you either run away after combo or you keep fighting. There are divers who pick PTA as three hits into burst, when they fight afterwards, then Skirmishers who pick Elec for three hits into burst then run away.

Literally If Elec showed the amount of stacks with the same graphic effect as PTA, suddenly the runes would be nearly identical. With PTA you trade away the reliability for dmg amp and smaller CD.

> (Also, Electrocute is technically AoE, but the radius is really tiny, so I won't nitpick about that.)

Just because it looks like that to you? Or do you have any way to prove it? Because you can get to PT, put two dummies extremly close and you'll see it deals damage only to specific one. There is no reason for it to be AoE, that would be such unnecesary decision.

PtA and Electrocute have as little in common as Electrocute and Phase Rush. All 3 of them have a 3-attack proc model, but vastly different effects, which are useful in completely different situations.
PtA is a supportive, team-wide keystone with back-loaded damage, good in large team-fights late game with no CD, whereas Electrocute is a very selfish, early game keystone with front-loaded damage, single target (or tiny AoE) and a big CD which prevents you to proc it on multiple targets. Except the way they proc, they have nothing in common.
On the other hand, what's the good situation to use Supernova? It's not large team-fights, even though it's AoE. Who are its intended users? Champs who want to dive in and burst a priority target. Those champ will pick Supernova and use it exactly as they use Electrocute, or so close that the difference won't be noticeable, I wager.
Also, PtA is in Precision, so gives AS, whereas Electrocute is in Domination and gives AD. Supernova would be in Sorcery, so gives AD just as Electrocute.

> There is no reason for it to be AoE, that would be such unnecesary decision.

I'm not sure about the new version since Rune Reforged, but the old version (Thunderlord's Decree in the previous Rune system) was 100% AoE, but with a radius of something like 25 units. The whole area was half a teemo wide, so basically the only way for it to affect multiple targets was if the second was dashing through your primary target at the moment you proc it. Very unlikely to happen in a real situation, that's why I said I wouldn't nitpick, but it was technically AoE.
Not sure about the new version, but I simply assumed they didn't change that aspect.
More sorcery keystones are always nice, and this one looks like it could have some potential.

Two worries: 1 is pushing champions taking this and poking the enemy to get the burst and using that to push in the wave, especially with a 35 second CD.  That could be fixed by making it champion only though.

The second one is that it prompts you to not want to poke your opponent because you lose out on all in potential.  Electrocute for example requires 3 damage instances, meaning that you can poke without losing your burst.  Meteor on the other hand comes up more the more you do poke, and is meant as a poke one in the first place.

I also just generally feel like it is a more niche version of Electrocute.  The champions you mentioned generally want to take out a single target as quickly as possible, Akali for her R reset, Diana because she is focused on trying to burst someone down in a very short amount of time.  None of them have much use for doing damage in a large AOE at the cost of single target burst, and post laning phase if their kill time takes 3 seconds then they are already going to be dead anyways or their damage is so low that this keystone wont make up for their lack of burst.

What I do see happening is J4 and other similar divers focused on AOE taking this, although most of them can just take aftershock for less damage in a smaller area, but with the resistances to actually live long enough to kill their opponents.  Of the people you listed I could see Elise taking it _purely_ because her mid-late game teamfight is a bit weak and it helps her provide some more damage for the team, and even then she would only be able to take it because spider form E lets her survive that long in a fight.

This is AOE around yourself and can be triggered by a single spell for weaker than comet power, or triggered by all your spells for a stronger than electrocute all in with teamfight utility that electrocute and comet lack.

The big selling point is this rune is made for somebody who wants to dive into a team and doesn't mind a little setup. Diana is a great user of this because she wants to land her Q before diving in of her own volition. Nidalee would be a great user too.

While this has some overlap with both aftershock and electrocute, being able to go sorcery domination would be a lot better for some Champs than resolve domination, purely for the stat boosts. Naturally that's just a playstyle choice between "do I want damage or durability?" 

J4 would definitely be a good user of this keystone though.

Okay but almost any champion can easily proc all 4 stacks, on a shorter CD than electrocute, for more damage, in a larger AOE with the only drawback being a 3 second delay, which cuts off a big group of users without inconveniencing the main users at all.  That is a pretty big power discrepancy with no drawback.
They also have to be in melee range for the damage, I intended for this rune to have a higher risk and reward than electrocute however the numbers are always up for tweaking
Could also work for mages if they're vs melee.

You might be able to simplify it with something like this:

>Wild Magic: Ranged aoe abilities apply a rune to enemies for 5 seconds, dealing X damage per second. Melee and single-target abilities detonate the rune, immediately dealing the rune's remaining damage in a large area and triggering all runes within the blast radius. Abilities will only detonate a rune every 60-40 seconds.

The idea with this is twofold:

1) Bring back DFT in some form, so we're talking a pretty small dot on the rune marks.

2) Give melee/hybrid mages a little extra for going balls deep. We're talking like an arcane comet worth of damage in a larger aoe and possible multi-hits in exchange for user restrictions, a timing restriction, and a much longer cooldown.

In the alternative:

>Critical strikes increase your attack speed and move speed, heal you to full, proc on-hit effects twice, shred enemy armor by 35%, and release an EMP pulse that disables all wards and traps in a 2000 radius. Any mages caught in the EMP become affected by True Death and will not resurrect, but their corpses can still be looted by spamming emotes or dancing on their graves.
